title: 106_hr3485
content: ENFORCEMENT OF CERTAIN ANTI-TERRORISM JUDGMENTS. The "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act" defines an 'agency or instrumentality of a foreign state' and specifies entities excluded from certain sections related to anti-terrorism judgments. The "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act" amends various sections of title 28, United States Code, including enforcement of judgments under section 1610(f) and technical amendments to section 1391(f)(3). It clarifies the attachment of moneys due from the United States to states with pending judgments under section 1605(a)(7). The "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act" allows for attachment and execution of judgments under section 1605(a)(7) against the United States. The President may waive this provision for national security reasons regarding property subject to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations or the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations, except if the property has been used for nondiplomatic purposes. The "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act" allows for attachment and execution of judgments against the United States, with exceptions for property subject to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations or the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. This includes assets that have been used for nondiplomatic purposes or sold/transferred to a third party. The terms 'property subject to the Vienna Convention' and 'asset subject to the Vienna Convention' refer to any property or asset whose execution would violate U.S. obligations under the respective conventions. The amendments made by the "Justice for Victims of Terrorism Act" allow for attachment and execution of judgments against the United States, with exceptions for property subject to the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations or the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations. All assets of any agency or instrumentality of a foreign state shall be treated as assets of that foreign state. Section 117(d) of the Treasury Department Appropriations Act, 1999 is repealed. These amendments apply to any claim for which a foreign state is not immune under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28, United States Code. The Paygo Adjustment prohibits the Director of the Office of Management and Budget from estimating changes in spending and receipts due to the Act. Technical amendments are made to improve litigation procedures and remove liability limitations. The amendment to Section 1605 of title 28, United States Code, allows for deeming failure to furnish testimony or documents as an admission of facts in actions involving foreign states. Additionally, Section 1605(a)(7)(B)(i) is modified to specify conditions for liability in cases where the act occurred in the foreign state. The amendment to Section 1605 of title 28, United States Code removes statutory limits on damages awarded to persons under certain sections. The amendments apply to claims where a foreign state is not immune under section 1605(a)(7) of title 28. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on July 25, 2000.
